Draught. Pours clear mahogany with a khaki head. Aroma is caramel and resiny hops. Taste is sweet with the bitterness following. Balanced. Good.

Bomber from Lakes market, santee. Pours a lovely amber-rouge hue with just the right fluffy, semi-dense pale brown sugar foam head. Aromas are all the right mix of pale malts and some specialty grains giving a nice cinnamon and sharp sugar/caramel notes. Taste is spot on: smooth, sweet, malty, and cleeeeaaaaannnnn finish. This is superior craftsmanship. Wow. They should be so proud of this beer. It is top shelf. Everything fits, malts, hops, ABV, all of it. Greatness. Even pick up on some wonderful citrus, passion, and stonefruit flavors from the hops in subsequent sips. Amazing.

What could be more perfect for Halloween? For a SoCal hop fan, AleSmiths Evil Dead Red is a perfect Halloween treat. It pours a reddish brown and has a fragrant hop aroma coming off the glass. The taste starts off with some chewy maltness that is quickly overcome by some sharp carbonation and a wild melange of hops. I get a little citrus, some fruit punch and some floral notes. And they are strong. But the whole thing is well balanced. You get some more cereal notes at the end to really round the beer off.
Bottle. Pours a deep amber with a red hue. Thin tan head. Strong hop aroma. Flavors of toasted malt and a nice sweetness. Chewy on the palate. Very well balanced and a good amber ale.

Poured from a bottle. Deep red with a huge beige head. Lots of lacing. Citrusy aroma. Malty up front with a hoppy finish. Would buy again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Taster @ the brewery. Clear amber pour, thin off-white head. Aroma is of caramel, floral hops, malty and fruity. Flavor is bitter with delicate hops, smooth malty sweetness and overall very well balanced. Great red ale.

22oz bottle, shared with local raters. Clear red-orange color. Thin khaki head. Dots of lace. Nice tropical fruity, spicy hop nose. Caramel, toasty malt. Big spicy earthy dry hop component. Bigger body. Smooth, crisp lighter carbonation. More dry finish. Pretty big bitter taste, light sweet. Some chocolate. Very hoppy, like a red IPA, basically. Very satisfying, tasty complex malt profile, though, so points for that. Orange citrus, grapefruit hop, very assertive. Spicy, toasty, caramel chocolate malt. Awesome stuff. Very nice long complex aftertaste.

Pour a dark amber with a two finger beige head wih fades to nice lacing. Aroma is of citrus, pine, sweet malts, caramel, bread pudding, and some toffee. Taste is citrus, pine, caramel, bread pudding, caramel malts, tofee, and some light tropical fruits. Has a medium-full body with a smooth, creamy mouthfeel and a semi bitter, medium long finish. Overall, a very nice amber ale that is very drinkable and is a nice fall sessional beer.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2016 October 2nd, 2014 - With Halloween around the corner its time for the Fall beers, typically ushered i with pumpkin ales and all kinds of other vegetal and spice ales. But Alesmith decorates differently, with a scary bottle and a spicy, tangy brew. The aroma is rusty, with a little bit of craft glue and cinnamon, all scents I associate heavily with preparation for the 31st. And, as if switching from preparation to Hallows Eve itself, the flavor has more chocolate, akin to the loot Id take home shortly before midnight at the end of this month. Theres a slight tang to it, and an earthiness rooted in cumin, giving both bright and bass-deep notes, covering a whole gamut of tastes. 

September 23rd, 2011 - I honestly cant remember the context or setting in which I tried AleSmiths Evil Dead Redemption, but I must have been hurried. My notes are short, curt, and actually, unsatisfying. According to my perfunctory and lazy scribblings, the tasting profile for this brew could be best summed up by referring to the ubiquitous Arrogant Bastard - a beer born just up the road in Escondido. That would imply that the Evil Dead Red is a fully flavored, hoppy and alcoholic brew that packs a wallop. I believe it. AleSmith never goes short on flavor, and if this brew is a clone of Arrogant Bastard, well, thats alright with me. (7/3/7/3/14/3.4)

Pours a clear deep amber color with a light taupe head. Sweet grapefruit leaps from the glass into the olfactory with some rich, sweet butterscotch that underlies it. Mouthfeel is light to medium-bodied with a bit of a carbonation scrub developing midway. Flavors are like a Milky Way bar with a tart cherry on top. Fine effort.
Growler from alesmith. Dark mahogany pour with nice head. Aroma is sweet caramel and sticky hops. Taste is very hoppy, sticky, chewy caramel. Frothy lower to med carbonation. Great red.

On tap at Alesmith it has a rich amber color in the glass. It has some nuts and caramel in the nose with a little bit of sweetness. Flavor has some toast and a resin quality to it. There is also a little bit of citrus and pine to it. Good finish.

Tap @ PP Carlsbad.  Dark amber pour with a slick of off-white foam.  Aroma is heavy with caramel and a slight charred malt character with light pine from the hops in the background.  Taste is a big caramel/malt flavor with noticeable char notes and complimentary hop bitterness in the finsh.  Smooth, almost creamy mouthfeel.  Nice beer.
On draft at alesmith. Pours a hazy dark amber with an ecru head. Fruity hop aroma. Hints of caramel. Bitter finish.
In pint on cask at Randy Jones BBQ.  Looks deep dark red.  Smells of simple good quality hops.  Tastes like a beautiful red ipa.  Good slight spice and smoothness from the cask. Overall 8 of 10

On tap at KnB.  Mahogany pour with nice one finger off white head. Excellent retention and lacing  Nose of bready malts and hops.  Taste follows with a nice level of hop bitterness and chewy sweet maltiness.  Similar to Brian Boru.

Thanks to Joe for the growler!  Poured crystal-clear, deep amber with a sticky cap of beige head.. lovely lacing as it descended.  The aroma picked up sweet, yet roasty caramel, nutty, and molasses notes, topped by a hefty dose of fruity hops and lesser pine & citrus.. just the faintest hint of peaty smoke too.. balance was spot-on.  The flavor found nutty and biscuity malts at the core, with additional layers of sweet caramel, vanilla, and molasses.. again the hop bill held up well, providing fruity and grainy earthy bitterness around.. some black peppery notes joined earthy bitterness and biscuity/nutty malts on the somewhat quick, dry finish.  Medium-bodied and dry on the palate with low carbonation.. just the right amount of bitters to cut through the interesting malts.. overall an excellent brew!
Tap @ Taproom.  Pour is dark amber; tons of lacing.  Malty aroma with some piney hops.  Very sweet and nutty taste with lots of hops.  Medium body is thicker than most reds.  Dry finish.  Very good.
Clear red pour at the brewery. Forever tan head. Nose is sweet hoppy ipa. Taste is ipa up front and light roast malt behind. Halfway to black ipa flavor.

Taster at the brewery. Pours amber with a small off-white head. The aroma is strong with pine resins, citrus and toffee. The taste is more of the same, lots of hops up front showcasing grapefruit and pine, followed by rich malts featuring toffee, caramel, pecans and walnuts. The palate is full and smooth with lively carbonation. Finishes long. Overall: Very nice--they should bottle this.

On tap at 38 Degrees.  Pours clear dark amber with a one finger light tan head.  The nose is malt, earthy hops and citrus.  The taste is caramel, light cocoa, coffee, grapefruit and some bitter resin in the finish.  Medium bodied.  Good brew.

Growler.  Pours a nice deep woody amber with a thin sticky off white head- good lace.  Aroma is big thick swet caramel malts, some toffee biscuit, nuts, earth and lots of good fresh green citrus hops, light pine and dusty leather.  flavor is caramel, toast, toffee, molasses slight burnt notes, pine and hops, orange and pine resin and sap and slightly oily from the hops.  Fresh and easy drinking- nice!

On tap at the tasting room.  This is Alesmiths Halloween beer...with an ABV of....6.66%...gotta love that.  Pours red with off white head.  Smells of malts dried fruit.  Has some mild hops to offset the sweetness.  Similar to Winter Yulesmith.

Appearance: Pours a deep dark red with a subsiding creamy head.

Aroma: Sweet, sugary malt, ripe fruit, burnt sugar. Finishes with piny abrasive hops.

Taste: Burnt sugar,brown sugar, dark bread and grapefruity hops.

Mouthfeel: Sticky with modest carbonation.

Overall: Very solid.  It has a similar malt profile to my favorite, Winter Yulesmith, but the hopping and sweetness is much more tame with this one.

Pours a rich red-brown color with nice off-white head. Aroma is a nice mixture of caramel malt and some piney hops. The caramel and roasty malt are nicely balanced throughout with a strong yet restrained bitterness. Very enjoyable.

I will try this again for a more accurate rating.

Poured Dark Reddish with medium head.
Roasty Malts and Strong Hop Nose.
Well balanced thoughout. Reminded me of a mellower Port Shark Attack.
medium body and medium carbonation.
Big Character!! definitely would drink this regularly.
Beautiful red pour with nice aroma of citrus hops and caramel candy malts. The taste pretty much reflects the aroma, however it finishes with a perfect balanced blend of bitter and sweet.

Growler fill from the brewery. Pours a deep clear brownish red color with a lingering head. Flavor is rich, toasty, roasted malts and a little bit chewy, little bit of ripe fruit in here as well. Balanced off with a nice mellow pine like hop bitterness. Medium bodied and smooth drinking. Up there as one of the better "Red" beers on the market.

on tap at alesmith as my first beer after stepping off the plane in SD. pours a rich, dark, garnet with a full, creamy, beige head leving nice rings of lace. aroma is great with with big, fresh, fruity hop notes of orange, grapefruit, fruit punch, and light berry backed by nutty malts, sweet toffee, and hints of pine. flavor is amazing with fresh, fruity, spicy hops notes of grapefruit, lemon, and pine esters with sweet berry notes showing up late and blending nicely with sugary, caramel malts. palate is medium bodied with great carbonation and a light bitterness that begs you to take another sip. overall, an awesome imperial red/american strong.

Poured from a growler generously sent by smokepot23 - thanks Joe! - I didnt to break into this as soon as I should have, so the carbonation is not what I am sure it should be, but still, Ive been waiting to try this for ages. Pours a fairly clear very beautiful deep mahogany red color. Because of the carbonation issues, there is only a tiny light tan head. But this really is a beautiful beer. Aroma is fairly hoppy with citrus and lemon notes, with sticky roasted caramel, touches of coffee and oak. A really nice aroma, but Im sure the hops shine through even more when fresh. Flavor is rich with toasted malts, deep caramel, fair amount of citrusy hops. Finish is mildly bitter but balanced with some residual sweetness. Palate is fairly thick. This is really good - Im sure its even better fresh, but still very good.

Tap at AleSmith 2-3 tasters later. So I like this but Im not sure what to think of it. Here comes another AleSmith offering- OMG it must kick ass. Well, this beer is pretty much just good beer and nothing too flamboyant. Obviously well attenuated with great lacing. The beer pours a deep cola brown with very good tan lace. Aroma is grapefruity hops, strawberries, red gummies. Taste is roasty, bready, sweet cola, muted fruity hops, perfect balance where you cant really pick out too much citrus hops or sweet malt. Sits perfectly neutral on the palate with just a little bite of carbonation. Really an excellent session brown ale.

This Red ale was a nice treat when I showed up to Alesmith this summer. I ended up getting a growler to go. There is a lot I could say about this beer, but that would take too long right now. I will add other notes when I try the beer again

A: The pour is what you would expect, a clear amber color with an emphasis on the red tones. A thin layer of off-white foam sits on top.

S: A great citrus aroma is the first thing I notice. A good amount of grapefruit and pine from the hops and a fairly well balanced amount of caramel and malt sweetness.

T: The taste is very similar to the nose. There is a nice citrus hop bite on the front, followed by a slight bit of caramel and toffee sweetness in the middle. The sip finishes with a rather pleasant bitterness.

M: Nothing spectacular in terms of body or carbonation, but certainly works well for the beer. Medium in body and carbonation.

D: This is a pretty darn tasty red ale. Im generally of the hoppy red ale persuasion, but this balanced one was actually quite nice.

On tap at City Beers AleSmith event.  Amazing appearance for this beer: clear deep red color with a nice off-white head and excellent lacing.  Aroma is caramel malts and fresh citrusy and piney hops.  Flavor is also caramel malt and piney/citrusy hops, typical of AleSmiths usual great hop profile.  Mild roast in there as well.  Perfect sweetness level.  Medium body with some hop resins on the palate and a slightly dry finish.  Very drinkable.  If you consider this to be an American amber/red ale, its really one of the better examples of the style out there.

Draft @ City Beer. Pours a deep, clear burgundy color; gorgeous head formation: creamy, light-tan, textured, with great retention and energetic lacing. Lots of red fruits and non-sticky caramel in the nose; cola, light sugar, hidden alcohol; a touch hollow at the core, but pleasant enough. Medium-to-full body: lots of earthy hop bitterness, red fruits, and caramel / creamy maltiness; nicely balanced, lots of fruit character, well-attenuated; seems like a very clear, light-bodied ASA. Medium, toasty finish: red fruits, hints of candy sugar, nicely dry.
Late entry from Noogfest High Five.  Hazy red pour with tan head.  Malty and sweet.  Pretty tasty, but not a standout.

On tap. Heard that this might not have been a particularly stellar keg. Pours with a hazed amber red body and an off-white head. Aroma of caramel, bread, toffee and floral hops. Taste is hops, and a bit chalky and dry with some caramel. Super well attenuated. Quite effervescent as well.
Ruby amber body, thick tan head. Aroma- roast caramel, citrus, dark fruit. Taste is rich thick malt sweetness with a bitter pine finish. Thick body, smooth carbonation.

On tap at PP Carlsbad.  Pour is a clear chestnut with a very dense creamy caramel colored head.  Suprised my how light this beer is, I was expecting something stronger.  Still quite enjoyable.  Caramel malts, fruit, herbal hops, bread, and earthiness.  Light on the palate, kinda in between an amber ale and american strong.  Complex and easy to drink.  The lacing is very nice, sticky rings all the way down the glass.  Overall a good beer, but in some ways lacking.

Pours amber-red with a thin, tan head. Aroma is citrusy and pine hops, malty earthiness. Earthy, with a slighly sour and somewhat hoppy finish. Comes together quite nicely, a refreshing and enjoyable red.

Pours a dark red brown with a thin egg shell head. 
Nose is juicy and fruity hop scents. Smells like amarillo. 
Taste is loaded with bright citrus and pine hops, juicy fruit, the middle is big and sweet, toffee, caramel, not bread, hints of biscuit, for the most party a fairly sweet sugary body with clean bitterness, and loads of hop flavor.

Draft at Stone Brewery. Deep ruby pour with a decent head. Dark malty aroma with a hint of hops. Nice kick in the flavor. Hit of citrus with some hops and malt. Earth like feel. Very good beer. Makes me love Alesmith even more.

Growler fill from brewery.  Pours an excellent deep garnet color with two fingers of thick off-white head.  Aroma of bright citrusy hops that is somehow very "earthy" at the same time.  Flavor is initially more citrus and earthy hops but is followed by rich malt tones.  It starts with a nice level of bitterness that gradually fades as the malt kicks in, though a little bitterness remains into the finish.  Ive already described this beer as "earthy" and somehow this makes it a great seasonal brew.  As with most all Alesmith beers, everything is balanced to near perfection here.  The relatively low ABV also helps to make this very drinkable.

On tap @ Beachwood BBQ.  Clear copper red with a small beige head, fair retention.  Pine and citrus rind hops dominate the aroma with plenty of scorched caramel and toffee behind.  Flavor adds some raisins, though not overly sweet.  Loads of fresh hops going on, with even some orange pulp going on.  Semi-dry with bitterness @ a 3-4.  Medium body with moderate carbonation.  Very good hoppy red--what Arrogant Bastard wants/wanted to be.  Rating 100 for this beer!
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: On tap at Alesmith. Pours very cloudy reddish/brown. Has a hoppy, dark malt nose. Taste is citrus hop and smooth, leaning towards IPA in style. Very nice!
Rust colored body with a big off-white head.  Aroma of pine and grassy hops.  The flavor is light malt, cardboard and plenty of grassy hops.  The weakest Decadence brew Ive had from Alesmith.

Sampled from growler courtesy hopscotch.  Copper-brown color, thin off-white light tan head .Fresh grassy sweet hop aroma with a nice latent maltiness.  Smooth malt on the taste, great citric hop character.  A great red.

On cask at The Linkery, San Diego.  Dark amber-red with a thin, very creamy light tan head and great lacing--quite a lovely pint.  Fresh resinous citrus and pine hops notes with a superbly balanced malt backbone and an alarmingly fresh earthiness in the aroma.  The flavor is malt-driven but in just the right amount so as to not be overly sweet or toasted.  It plays very well with the citrusy, resinous hops flavors and has a perfect "autumnal" feel to it.  The body is super smooth here on cask and gives a delicate delivery of this amazingly structured beer.

Tap at SDBC.  Deep red-amber beer wit a thick creamy off-white head that sticks around for ever.  Aroma is full of bright fruity hops.  Cascadey grapefruit and a touch of orange peel as well as a soft sweet toasted matliness that forms the backbone of this beer.  A lovely soft sweetness that has a bit of dried fruit and a soft toasted nutty sweetness.  Fantastically rich palate with a soft creamy body that accentuates the malty sweetness but also showcases the bright citrusy hops in here.  Moderate bitterness but there is a lot of fruity hoppiness.  Man... this is just a fantastic beer.

growler courtesy of hopscotch: pours a good crimson red slight tan head. aroma is a great citrus hop, lemon, grapefruit, nice sweet malts behind all teh hops. flavour is very earthy with hops being grassy decent malt a little bitter in the finish.

malty fruity with raisins and hop presence all in the nose.  slight alcohol.  ruby in color.  low lacing and head.  lots of legs due to alcohol.  sweet as well.  expected more hops in taste but they are there.  more than your average red ale.

Tap @ Hamilton’s.  Pours clear auburn with a skimpy white head.  Caramel, grapefruit, and pine dominate the nose.  Full, tangy grapefruit and resin hop flavor tempered nicely by the malt.  The caramel thankfully does not overwhelm.  Velvet mouthfeel.  I just can’t get enough of the hops in this one.  Its so good.

Dominate hop flavor, with an excellent malt to match.  Hops are similar to their perfect IPA, but the malt is much stronger and more pronounced.  Lots of caramel and cherry notes coming through, even with all the hops, and mostly rides with the 6.66 ABV.  Another winner from Alesmith.

Cask at Callahan’s in San Diego. The brew pours a clear dark reddish-amber color with a thick and foamy beige head that diminishes slowly. Thin sheet of sticky lacing on the glass. The aroma is rich and malty with notes of piney hops and fruit. Medium, smooth body with a hops and malt presence that complement each other well. Also notes of toasted read, pine and fruits. The finish is clean and fruity. Overall this was enjoyable, and I definitely want to try it on the tower sometime as the cask most likely muted some of the more robust flavors.

Thanks Hopscotch!  Right from the growler, pours a dark amber with a strong hop smell and a hoppy background.  The alcohol comes through in the smell but not as much in the flavor.  The balance is almost perfect.  Great hoppy red.

Tasting at the McBackus Backyard Bash. Thanks to Hopscotch for the taste and my #800! Deep reddish brown pour. Spicy hops, very fresh, with a nice earthy citrus quality. Big hop taste, fresh and spicy, citrus and pine just awesome. Nice smooth malt, good mouthfeel. Just a slight bitterness in the finish. Very good.

Ultra-fresh growler, courtesy hopscotch.  Pours a really dark, reddish, sienna brown color.  A frothy, cream colored head shows good retention, leaving obtuse, foamy spots of lace on the glass.  The aroma is massively hoppy, bitter pine resin leading the charge, followed by sharp grapefruit and orange peel notes.  The malt base shows caramel, toffee, and toasted biscuit on the nose.  Flavors follow suit, rich caramel and toffee being balanced by sticky pine hops and strikingly bitter, fresh grapefruit.  Medium-full bodied, with balanced carbonation, the palate is smooth and highly drinkable.  Grapefruit and pine linger on the finish.  This is a damn fine brew.  One of the better imperial reds out there, for sure.
Sampled @ Backuss Backdoor Bash.Poured from a growler courtesy of Hopscotch.Poured a dark amber with a thin lacing head.Had a huge piney hop nose.Was a total hop bomb here, not my favorite.
Growler courtesy of the Merrit Island tasting hosted by mcbackus. Sweet malts up front with some oranges and lemons. Finish was wood, grass, and hops. Lots of hops for me.

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2008 Growler... Backuss Backdoor Bash 08... Clear ruby ale with a small, creamy, khaki head. Good retention. Piney, citrusy aroma with caramel and toasty nuances. Medium to full-bodied and lightly creamy with moderate carbonation. Hearty caramel malt and low acidity are evident, but not the focus. Earthy, citrusy hop flavor steal the show. Finishes bitter, raspy and dry. Thanks go out to smokepot23 for getting this growler to me fresh and cold... from across the country!

Tasting at mcbackus 10/19.  Growler came from smokepot23.  Great beer.  Reddish brown pour, small tan head.  Aroma of citrus, pine, toasted bread and malt.  Flavor is malty, bitter, hoppy, just really well balanced.  This was the my first taste out of a growler ever.

Dark amber hue, good clarity, thick pillowy off-white head sustains. Aroma is moderate pine and resin, light grass, moderate caramel, toast, and biscuit in the back. Nice balance of big sweet caramel malts with piney hops, light hop bitterness, light fruit esters in the middle, touch of chalk and grass near the end, finishes medium dry. Palate is medium-bodied, thick and chewy malt texture, mild carbonation. Overall, a smooth and balanced hop flavored amber, nice mix of sweet caramel with modest pine hops, very drinkable.

Poured from a fresh growler courtesy of Dmac, thanks Dave and also thanks to Padrefan for sending this Jersey-way. Pours out a nice deep reddish hued brown with a nice small to moderate sized off white head.  Aroma is of citrus/resiny hops with some touches of caramel and grain. Taste is complex and wonderfully balanced. Notes of caramel and grain are perfectly balanced by a nice citrus hop presence. Hops more intense on the aroma, but still there throughout the beer. As always very well done by Alesmith.

Growler from the best darn RBer on the west coast padrefan98, thanks Jon. Pours a great looking deep brown/red with an awesome looking frothy light beige head that leaves some serious lace on my Duvell tulip. Very hoppy aroma with tons of grapefruit and citrus with a nice caramel sweetness in the background. Medium bodied with light to medium carbonation. The hops drop of drastically in the flavor and your punched in the mouth by a fistful of malts...caramel, toffee, biscuit and grains followed up with a nice hop finish. This is one great beer but I’m calling shenanigans on that ABV rating of 6.66%, SHENANIGANS!!!

On tap; pours a nice auburn hued red with a khaki colored head.  Aroma of grapefruit, fruit and flowers; bursting with aroma.  Very flavorful and balanced beer.  Some of the best flavor for the style that I have had in a while.  Bitter and strong flavored, but not overpowering.  Malty, fruity, caramelly with some floral/citrus elements.  Very good for the style.

Draft @ O’Brien’s San Diego.  Pours a deep ruby/ amber color that was mostly clear with an off white head that left great lacing.  Tons of floral and citrus hops on the nose as well as some malt.  The flavor had a nice hop bit with a malty back bone.  Glad I finally got to try this beer, well worth the wait!!

a damn great red ale
super nice hoppy aroma...balanced by a great malt sweetness....wish it was year around!

super aroma of spicy floral hops.  beautiful red color with nice white lacing.  medium body with some chewy carmel flavors an hop presence.  nice beer, thanks to cbkschubert for this hand bottled beer.

On tap at the 07 Speedway BA Release.  Lots of growlers being filled up.  I can see why, it was a stunning brew.  Rich amber color, nice hop, malt, floral deep aroma.  Very balanced, no alc noticable.  Very easy drinker.  Complex, for some reason it seemed like Pliny meets YuleSmith.  Thus very high quality.  Keg only, hope to see it around town very soon!

Growler from the brewery. Pours hazy dark red with a creamy, offwhite head, soider web lace. Smells dark and red fruit sweet malty with a nice balance between the malt and hop scents. Tastes sweet caramelly malty smooth with a slight bitter red hop presence. Smooth and balanced. Full body, good carbonation.

Growler from the brewery - Pours a reddish-brown color with a medium size off white head.  Light lacing.  Aroma is pine and citrus hops and sweet toasted malt.  Flavor is the same thing.  Has a smooth, easy drinking finish.  Medium body.  Alesmith needs to bottle this stuff.  Nice!
Growler from the brewery released 9/26/2008. Fresh hops and roasted malts. Wonderful balance. Absolutely evil!

Growler from the brewery. Beautiful color, dark red. It really does look evil, and delicious. Nice hoppy,piney aroma, really nice. Really nicley balanced brew, nice roasty malts and smooth glorious hops. Wonderful beer.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Growler fill at Brewery. Nice hop aroma. Pine, mango resin, citrus blended nicely with the malt. Nice balance. Dry finish. A good one for sure.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2009 Growler fill from the brewery. Deep almost opaque golden mahogany. Wonderful hop aroma. Starts good with a malty sweetness then bitters from hops fill the mouth with some pine hints and a slight alcohol flavor.. Ends with a long dry finish. Very good beer, warming and tasty!
pours a flat dark amber brown.  sweet malty sweet sugar, light and smooth, not too heavy.  dry finish.  sweet and malty with a low complexity to it, good.

Growler from the brewery. Deep red-brown color, with a good-sized light head. Complex flavors of hops, malt, and citrus. Taste fades away smoothly, changing into a bit of a sharp bite at the end. Very nice ale.
On tap at Pizza Port Carlsbad.  Very red dark amber color.  1 finger creamy head.  Well balanced sweetness and hops.  Nice hop flavor with low hop bitterness.  Decent session ale.
No Killians, for sure!  My simple mind classifies this as somewhat sweeter than the AleSmith IPA, with a little added dry coffee finish.  An absolute joy on tap.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2009 Growler from WeeHeavySD. Dark rudy color with light tan/amber head.Wonderful aroma of Fruity citrus hops and toasted chocolate malt. The taste was like the aroma with prickley piney hop finish. Nice balance and light sweetness throughout. The finish was watery but in a good way. Never thought Id ever say that. Glad I finely got a chance to try this brew. Thanks!!

Deep bronze in color, this ale smelled deliciously of a fruit smoothie, betraying strawberries, raspberries, and yeast. The first swig tasted something deceivingly evil, every bit as creamy and fruity as the aroma. However its true color became apparent mid-goblet, as the iron jaws of hops clamped down on my taste buds. A fugue of yeast, hops, and Candi sugariness was the climax of this dire symphony. All that remained was a powdery, cream-colored lacing.

Very dark blood red colour (how appropriate!) with a large and dense tan head. There is quite a bit of hops in this sucker, giving a piney and citrus IPA like aroma. Feels like a bigger bolder amber ale with a huge dose of hops. Little sweet in there also with a dusty chocolate finish. This is kind of run-of-the-mill but it sure as hell impresses.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2007 growler, thanks to Jon (WeeHeavySD)! pours dense dark ruby with big creamy tan head. nose has big citrusy and piney with toasty and sweet caramelly malt notes. flavor is rich with fresh citrusy hop notes along with big nutty malty finish and a very mild chocolate in the very end of the finish. sweet and citrusy but a watery finish. smooth carbonation. perhaps Im expecting beers with this much complexity to not be this drinkable or seemingly this thin/watery. im begining to see how delicate AleSmith beers are. never really had anything like it. i think this could benefit with a bit more body and up the alcohol to 7-7.5%abv (but i guess thats more what Decadence 06 was). however, its still a really tasty hopped up red ale and a wonderful session ale.
God thats a good red ale.  Delicious, full in flavor, a bit dry.  Ale smith continues to impress.

text: Growler fill.  Deep copper redu with a foamy head.  Rich caramel and hoppy aroma.  Caramel, citrus, and pine taste with a decent bitterness and a dry finish.
On tap at AleSmith Brewery. Interesting brew, pours a dark amber with thick head. Brew smells hoppy but taste really malty. Balance is a little weird but seems to work. Average brew by AleSmith

This dark brown ale poured with a fluffy beige head and a strong malt aroma. There is a complex, yet balanced flavor that includes sweet malt, citrus, bitter hops and raisins. This is a unique and interesting brew.
I believe it is a bit overrated. Hated it at the great escape. It was good beer indeed.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2007 On draft.  I love AleSmith - and this beer is no exception.  Its nothing spectacular, but its a great beer when youre in the mood for something a bit lighter.  The great malt background was the highlight of this deep rich and mahogany colored ale.  Very balanced and easy to put down

Pour warm reddish color with a light beige head....smell is sweet and caramel at first, then grap[efruit and soapy as the hops come out...taste is lightly sweet up front with some caramel and molasses, then hoppy and bitter is it finishes...

best red ale ever.  on tap at liars club.  deep red color with creamy off white head. carmel, nutty, west coast hoppy, with bits of orange citrus flavors.  Almost a nitro feel with the creamy mouthfeel.  Very freakin cool.

From draught.  Deep, mahagony ruddy pour with even clarity and a healthy layer of creamy head.  Fresh aromas of strawberries and blackberries create a ripened berry background to the well balanced, slightly spicy hop character.  Some juicy, sweetened ruby red grapefruit completes the bouquet nicely.  Medium bodied, effervescent mouthfeel that compliments the malty body quite well.  Flavors of cherries and strawberries come out well behind a malty graham cracker base.  A touch of floral hops kiss the tongue gently in the final smack.

On tap at Pizza Port, Carlsbad. As an American Strong Ale, this agains charts new waters for me, as I find the amber ale characters to be richly infused in this example. Aroma has a light sweet cherry and brown sugar wasp, with some molasses and a whole blast of sweet malt and fringes of Cascade. Orange-hued deep amber florid color, with a creamy off-white head. Incredibly creamy malt flavor. It explodes in lucious foam on the tongue, sending forth brandied sugars and some edges of resiny hops. Intensely smooth, deeply rich with malt character. The balance here is inexplicably some of the best Ive recently experience, with all angles of hop character meeting at various facets of the presentation to combine with the outstanding malting to create a delicious beer. Nicely done!

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2009 On Tap @ the Liars Club. Clear amber color with nice creamy tan head. Full aroma of caramel malts and orange to grapefruit hops. Nice mix of caramel malt sweetness and grapefruit hop bitterness. I love hoppy red ales. There are enough malts to compete and even win over the aggressive hops. Well done.

Hazed bloody crimson red, creamy tan head.  Nose was an interesting mix of toasted dark sweet malt, hints of roasted chocolate, touches of cherry and grapefruit, with just a slight note of cooked veggies. Toasty malt flavors throughout that balance with earth and citirc hop tones. More malt here for sure with slight chocolate and mild coffeeish notes from start to finish.  Medium bodied, medium carbonation, soft bittersweet finish.  An Alesmith session brew without a doubt.  Good stuff...

Fresh growler from the brewey.  deep red/brown with a great beige head. Aroma is hoppy, but the flavor is heavier on the malyt side, with hop flavor in the finish, but not enouhg to make is super bitter like the rater bveofe me said, this beer really does feel much bigger than it easy.  alesmith really knows how to crank out the good stuff. Im so glad I live in SD.

On tap at Alesmith. Pours deep red with a large off-white head. Aroma is quite hoppy and appetizing. Flavor is more malty than anything with a nice bitter finish. This beer is surprisingly full bodied given the low ABV.
Cask, OBriens. Pours a slightly hazy ruby color. Strong citric hoppy aroma. Slightly sweet smooth hoppiness. Very smooth drinker with a bit of a hoppy bitter finish.

This quality ale is dark with a fair amount of carbonation. The aroma is hops with a citrus whiff. The flavor is filled is filled licorice and a smooth fig finish. On tap at Labellas in Chula Vista in pitchers and Liters. This ale is the ninth wonder of the world!!!!!!!
UPDATED: OCT 28, 2007 On tap at the brewery. Reddish brown color, hoppy aroma, mild flavor. Its a nice session brew

Tap at Hollingshead Deli. Deep mahagony with ruby highlights, generous tan head. Aroma mostly piney grassy citrus hops. Nice roasty caramel "red" malty character, lots of hop flavors to balance, llingering bitterness that underlines the finish. Very well designed brew, I need a growler!

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2007 On tap at Porters Pub on the UCSD campus.  Ive been dieing to try this brew for some time and it was certainly worth the wait.  The brew pours a dark amber that is very dark and almost black at the top of the glass and lightens slightly as it goes down.  The head was very thin.  The scent was light but had a nice heave malty aroma.  The taste is a fantastic blend of hops and malts.  Although the malt predominates as it should with a red ale, the hops come through nicely and create an even balanced delicious feel.  There is no real aftertaste and the brew goes down mighty smooth.  get it if you can.  Upon re-rate damn does pour like blood, and for this Im a vampire.
Malty enough for me, finished nice with some hop flavor, some citrus hints in it, pretty balanced brew, better than expected for me. Draft at Stuffed Sandwich

(Draught, Stuffed Sandwich)  Pours a murky reddish-brown body with a medium-sized beige head.  Aroma of light roastiness, candish malt, toffee, and some notes of fruit.  Nice balance of hops and malt with some fruitiness and spices in the finish.

On tap pours nice mahogany with a lasting white head. Nice hoppy nose with a malt backbone. Great balance of bitterness and malts with a brilliant dry hoppy finish. Another great yearly release from AleSmith.

I had some of this on cask at the Quaff brew club meeting last October.  Pretty damn tasty stuff.  Better than your average red.  Im not a big cask kinda guy, but if I had the chance, I would have gotten screwed up and thrown the lightshade on my head.  Its that good.

Sampled at Alesmith, early Dec 05.  Brown pour.  Cirtus hops, and a big malty caramel aroma.  Big caramel malty flavors, with a good amount of citrus hops, and some notes of medium fruits.  Clean finish, with no bitterness.  This was insanely good, without a palate killing bitter finish.

Sampled from a growler shared by BobSandage:  Pours a deep, dark copper brown with a nicely-lacing light tan head.  Has a great fresh hoppy aroma with some sweet dark caramel maltiness.  Starts with a full malty toffee gritty sweetness well balanced with a fresh, green piney hop flavor.  A very nice, dangerously drinkable brew and another winner from Alesmith.  I sure wish theyd bottle this.  Thanks Bob!

Tap at Papago. Palate was dry and need a good beer and got one. Great citrus orange aroma stands out. Believe this was a dark amber body but the pub is dark so hard to tell. Decent creamy tan head that left good lacing on the glass. Had a creamy citrus orange flavor. Fruity aftertaste and somewhate of a dry palate. Great brew.

Draft at San Diego Brewing Co.  Definitley red with a smallish head that didnt last all that long.  Aromas were very hoppy with pine and other floral notes.  Flavors were somewhat citrusy, but with some nice sweet malts in there too.  A little bit of toated bread made gave the flavor an interesting finish.  Very good stuff.

Grolwer thanks to BobSandage.  Poured a deep ruby color with an off-white head.  Hoppy aroma that starts out citrusy then earthy.  Malty underneath with some notes of cherry.  Flavor was malty, nutty, toasty with hops mingling throughout.  Light mild bitter finish.  Medium body.

This beer was on cask at OBriens.  The aroma was malty sweet, caramel, a very slight roasty note, and big citrus and oranges.  The flavor was malty w/ slight roast note, citrus and big oranges.  The beer poured a cloudy reddish brown color w/ golden orange highlights; slight lasting head and lace.  The mouthfeel was medium bodied and creamy.

Pours a deep red almost mahogeny color with a medium sized off- white head.  THe aroma is very smooth with hints of citrus and lots of pine.  The flavor is very similar, but better.  I can taste the malt and the pine very strongly in the flavor.  Overall a very enjoyable beer and I like this batch more than the last one!

This beer has a frothy light tan head that sits atop a deep amber colored beer that is quite clear.  The aroma is fortifingly hoppy with notes of pine, grapefruit and a nice herbal note.  Oh yes this is packed with hops, bracingly bitter from the get go.  I get notes of orange peel in the finish as well.  There is some sweet malt here as well, but it is almost drowned out by the pure hoppiness of this beer.  The hops are quite refreshing though, after a night of hopless beer sampling.  This beer has lots of herbal hop notes to it, there is citrus character here as well, but it really is most evident in the finish once the malt sweetness is finally able to assert itself.  I get notes of candied orange in the finish, this beer is almost abusively bitter, yet it is still quite appetizing.  My only complaint, this beer could use a bit more malt complexity to stand up to the hop onslaught.

I cant believe I havent rated this yet!  I went through a whole keg of the stuff and somehow forgot, hehe.  Ill revert to the boring rating style for this beer only.  Aroma is wonderfully malty with floral hops providing a firm background.  Taste is zippy berry fruit, citrus hops, and sweet malts and a tad of roasted barley off the back.  Finish is perfect.  Such a joy to drink 5 whole gallons, believe me :)  I look forward to this every year.
On tap at Fathers Office in Santa Monica. Transparent red with a smal white head. First taste is of smooth fruit that finishes more crisp thanks to the generous hop flavor. Great stuff.

On tap at AleSmith.  Nice crystal clear reddish pour, small whitsh head.  Hops preside over the malts,  wonderful aroma.  Wonderful flavor dominated mostly by the hops, but this is a great beer.  Red obviously refers to the color, not the style, but thats here nor there.  This is a great beer.  Until next year!

clear crimson is the color, with a wafer-thin layer of beigey foam topping this glass...large fruity sweetness in the nose, a burgundy blast, buttressed with hops, rosey and ripe, vibrant and raw, very fresh hop feel...damn, but I like it, for it really seems like raw hop cones crawling up into the nose. Now, to drink away...
Brash, fresh, tasty mouthfeel, soon subsiding, but a blast while it lasts. Dark fruit, and raw hops, again. Juicy cherry and berry, with a solid net of malt beneath, though not really felt through the flavor. About medium in body, with a soft, fruity finish. The appeal here, though, is all up front in this great buzz of tasty hoppiness that blazes across the palate. Not like any other red ale Ive encountered before, way tastier than any of them, more heavy on the hops than the malt...one of a kind, here, no surprise from Alesmith.
Id return to this quite often were I a San Diegoan...as it stands, Ill cherish every drop of this growle

Sampled draught at OBriens, San Diego.
Clear reddish brown. Big lychee hop aroma. Sweet, yet soft with rounded filling mouthfeel. The finish is bitter, but not overly so. An extrovert red ale.

(Draft: San Diego Brewing Co. in San Diego, CA) Strongly hoppy, moderate grapefruit flavor is dominant, and so far, I like this a lot; But the maltiness is pretty light and subdued, and once the initial hops fades away, the finish is pretty uneventful, thin and short lived; The nose is very hoppy with obvious grapefruit aromas; The color is deep red and dark amber; Light tan head is bubbly and quickly settles to a thin sheen with some clumps of large bubbles; Patchy lacing is left on the glass
Smells of an IPA. Clear ruddy brown color. A cutting type of bitterness is what this beer is built upon. I like how the hops take charge and never let the malts do much damage.

Draft, poured clear dark reddish-amber with a thick off-white head that lingered nicely and left some lacing.  Srong citrus-hoppy aroma with some mild sweet maltinesss and hints of spice.  Flavor dominated by hops - lots of grapefruit rind notes - pleasant roast malts with a bit of maple and clove in the finish.  Medium body, creamy carbonation.  Nice brew.
This is an excellent brew.  Its very easy to drink and is full of flavor.  Chinook hops are of note in the nose and flavor.  Clean finish.

Excellent color and taste to this ale. 
Also like the nicely done dry finish and no aftertaste. Very well done.
A fine, fine red brew.  Had it on tap at the brewery and couldnt get enough.  Great aroma, color, and palate!
UPDATED: SEP 21, 2004 I too had this on cask and wasn't overly impressed. Nice red color and smooth mouthfeel. Not as hoppy as I'd like but has a nice malt finish.

On cask at the Liar's Club.  Nice earthy-red tint with a great malt and hop balance.  Easily one of the better English Strong Ales I've had, with an added bonus of drinkability.  I could handle two or three pints of this or drink it on a regular basis, which is harder to say about other Alesmith releases.
Had at the Alesmith brewery in San Diego.  Red color with a decent sized  off-white head.  Aroma is mainly hops and very floral.  Flavor is hops and malt in balance.  Nothing really stands out.
Had this on tap, and tasted flat.  Maybe not flat, but it was very smooth, with a hint of roasty malt and a hint of hops.

This brew pours with a beautiful reddish body topped by a medium thick foamy off-white head with good lacing.  The aroma is slighlty sweet and well balanced leaning towards grapefruity hops.  The flavor is sweet and grapefruity from the hops with a good malty balance and a nice grapefruity hop finish.  Medium bodied and very smooth.

A copper colored body with a full, lively white head.  The aroma was surprisingly hoppy.  Dripping wet citrus fruit, sticky pine sap with a bit of caramel and grainy malt.  The flavor had a nice balance of malt and hop characteristics.  Not an incredibly unique or creative beer, but one with good flavor that is well made.  Many thanks to Peter for allowing me an opportunity to try this rare ale.
Deep copper with a tan creamy head. Citrus hop aroma and maybe some Crystal Malt. Bitterness is big up front then the malt kicks in. Med bodied and dry. Overall just kind of there.
Big copper colored brew. Big malt front with a huge hop back running to the rescue. Creamy palate.Excellent session brew if you could get it.
UPDATED: FEB 9, 2003 Murky orange topped off with a nice and creamy head..unassuming aroma..slight hoppiness carried by pineapple and cherries..some drinkable stuff here..oh yes..

Rating of October 23, 2002 - On tap at CallahansA bit nuttier than I remember the second time around, this beer is still a very good red ale.  The beer does not overwhelm you with the hoppy taste of others and just looks beautiful sitting in front of you with the nice, dark reddish-brown color.  On tap at Callahans, the beer had very little head, but packs plenty of flavor.Rating of October 19, 2002 - Unveiling @ AlesmithA very good red ale.  I had this at the Alesmith Evil Dead Reawakening on Oct. 18, 2002.  We had one of the very first pints from the tap and it was amazing.  My first go at the Evil Dead - most defintely not my last.  An opaque, dark mahogany color, the beer has a slight head.  The beer is very drinkable with a hoppy taste that doesnt overwhelm.  It finishes quite nicely with a smooth malty flavor - highly recommended.  The 2002 brew, with its nice 6.2 ABV, is a nice pick-me-up for this coming holiday season.

Cloudy, dark red/mahogany color with a  thin quick fading tan head. A little hops in the nose. Rich sweet malt flavor balanced perfectly with a nice hop bitterness. Lingering dry, orangy aftertaste. It's a 'Quaffer' Tod !!! 
9/22/03: Same song second verse. Rich, smooth, creamy with a nice hop finish. One of AleSmith's best specialty draft beers.
12/10/03: Seems to have mellowed nicely with a few months aging. Thanks Peter!

I love Alesmith, an this beer does not disapoint.  Great dark red, mahogany color.  thin brown head that disapears fairly swiftly.  very well balanced between the sweet malt and the hops.  these guys are hopheads but this time the hops are not so much for bittering as they are for flavoring and aroma.  another masterpiece!

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2003 A great beer. I am always a big fan of the red ales, but this one is simply amazing. Great color, great name and label, and the blend of malt and hop flavors is absolutely perfect. Thumbs up to alesmith.
very, very nice.  nice sweetness, balanced beautifully by pleasant citrusy hops (especially brilliant when served cask conditioned and dry hopped)

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2004 Draught @ Papago
The beer as it sets in the glass a deep sanguineous color with a stupendous creamy light tan head that last for a week, well almost, the lace a thick and sticky sheet to obfuscate the glass. Nose is cotton candy like in sweetness, nice aroma of hops, clean and fresh to the senses, start is sweet, decent malt presence and the top middling in feel. Finish is strict in its acidity with the hops pleasantly spicy and the dry aftertaste lingers long on the palate.
